description: Borrowed from Latin geniculātus (“with bended knee”), from geniculum (“little knee”) +‎ -ātus (“-ate”, adjectival suffix).

entries.meaning: (anatomy, botany) Bent abruptly, with the structure of a knee.
examples: a geniculate stem; a geniculate ganglion; a geniculate twin crystal

entries.meaning: Having kneelike joints; able to bend at an abrupt angle.

verbs.description: geniculate (third-person singular simple present geniculates, present participle geniculating, simple past and past participle geniculated)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare, transitive) To form joints or knots on.
